name: osquery
description: SQL powered operating system instrumentation, monitoring, and analytics.
contribution_justification: Non-trivial contribution file in repository: <https://github.com/osquery/osquery/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/osquery/osquery/blob/master/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification:
osquery is released under a dual license -- Apache-2.0 & GPL-2.0

https://github.com/osquery/osquery/blob/master/LICENSE
documentation_basics_justification: Documentation is pushed from the main repository to https://osquery.readthedocs.io
documentation_interface_justification: There are a variety of external interfaces. They are primarily documented in https://osquery.readthedocs.io
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: To some degree, the head branch is where most collaborative review happens. Though we have made a handful of interim versions. (for example https://github.com/osquery/osquery/releases/tag/4.0.0
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification: We use semvar, as represented by git tags
version_tags_justification: We use semvar, as represented by git tags
release_notes_justification: Release notes are currently written into the github https://github.com/osquery/osquery/releases page. We're looking at creating a dedicated file for this.
report_tracker_justification: The project uses GitHub issues to track bugs, known problems, questions, and feature requests https://github.com/osquery/osquery/issues
report_responses_justification: osquery has recently transitioned. We're working through the issue backlog.
build_justification:
osquery builds with cmake. This is is tested through the CI system. See https://osquery.readthedocs.io/en/stable/development/building/

Non-trivial build file in repository: <https://github.com/osquery/osquery/blob/master/CMakeLists.txt>.
build_common_tools_justification:
osquery builds with cmake. This is is tested through the CI system. See https://osquery.readthedocs.io/en/stable/development/building/

Non-trivial build file in repository: <https://github.com/osquery/osquery/blob/master/CMakeLists.txt>.
build_floss_tools_justification: As far as I'm aware, all components are FLOSS
test_justification: Project use cmake's ctest as a framework.
test_invocation_justification: Project use cmake's ctest as a framework, this is documented as part of the build instructions. https://osquery.readthedocs.io/en/latest/development/building/
test_policy_justification: For all non-trivial work, we informally require test coverage.
warnings_justification: See the cmake configuration for the project https://github.com/osquery/osquery/blob/master/cmake/flags.cmake
warnings_fixed_justification: See the cmake configuration for the project https://github.com/osquery/osquery/blob/master/cmake/flags.cmake, Werror is set.
warnings_strict_justification: See the cmake configuration for the project https://github.com/osquery/osquery/blob/master/cmake/flags.cmake, Wall and pedantic among others are set.
crypto_published_justification: The places where osquery uses cryptograph, it uses common libraries.
crypto_call_justification: osquery is not a cryptographic toolkit
crypto_keylength_justification: osquery doesn't use security mechanisms, per se. It's a tool that reads local APIs. When it communicates with a remote server, it uses a push mechanism. It does not accept incoming connections
crypto_working_justification: osquery doesn't use security mechanisms, per se. It's a tool that reads local APIs. When it communicates with a remote server, it uses a push mechanism. It does not accept incoming connections
delivery_mitm_justification: Software is generally distributed via https. Releases are signed.
dynamic_analysis_justification: osquery has multiple fuzzing harnesses run by oss-fuzz periodically. You can find the configuration in the oss-fuzz GitHub repo https://github.com/google/oss-fuzz/tree/master/projects/osquery and the logs from the fuzzers on the oss-fuzz build status page https://oss-fuzz-build-logs.storage.googleapis.com/index.html#osquery
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: osquery has multiple fuzzing harnesses run by oss-fuzz periodically. You can find the configuration in the oss-fuzz GitHub repo https://github.com/google/oss-fuzz/tree/master/projects/osquery and the logs from the fuzzers on the oss-fuzz build status page https://oss-fuzz-build-logs.storage.googleapis.com/index.html#osquery
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: Project uses GitHub Actions/workflows. Configured via https://github.com/osquery/osquery/tree/master/.github/workflows and as a requirement on PRs.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
hardening_justification: Stack protectors, full relro, and other compiler-available hardening options are used https://github.com/osquery/osquery/blob/master/cmake/flags.cmake
crypto_used_network_justification: To the extent possible the project enforces best practices for TLS connections https://github.com/osquery/osquery/blob/master/osquery/remote/transports/tls.cpp#L146
hardened_site_justification: // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
installation_common_justification: The convention is to use the published packages for various operating systems (deb, rpm, msi, pkg).
build_reproducible_justification: With the use of the osquery-toolchain, all dependencies are currently built from source in a reproducible way. PR where osquery-toolchain was merged https://github.com/osquery/osquery/issues/5609
implementation_languages: C++, Python, CMake, Objective-C++, PowerShell, Shell, C, Thrift, Batchfile
roles_responsibilities_justification: The project has a Technical Steering committee (TSC) defined by the charter in the following repository https://github.com/osquery/foundation office hours are kept and the roles are defined by GitHub teams within the GitHub organization.
access_continuity_justification: There are 6+ people on the TSC, whom have control over the GitHub organization, and whom regularly perform code review and merge actions https://github.com/orgs/osquery/teams/technical-steering-committee
bus_factor_justification: See above and the GitHub team https://github.com/orgs/osquery/teams/technical-steering-committee
documentation_roadmap_justification: The osquery project plans for its next 1-2 milestones (2-4 months), not 1 year horizons. http://github.com/osquery/osquery/milestones There are long-term goals in a future milestone, but the contributions to the project are not consistent enough to plan 1 year roadmaps.
documentation_architecture_justification:
https://github.com/osquery/osquery/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+label%3Ablueprint+
Project uses issues tagged as blueprint for high-level designs
documentation_security_justification: This is defined https://github.com/osquery/osquery/blob/master/SECURITY.md and parsed and supported by the GitHub project security features https://github.com/osquery/osquery/security
documentation_quick_start_justification: Please see the documentation on ReadTheDocs, which begins with a quick start tutorial https://osquery.readthedocs.io/en/latest/
documentation_current_justification: The documentation is built on each pull request, errors will prevent merging https://github.com/osquery/osquery/blob/master/.readthedocs.yml
documentation_achievements_justification: The README for the project contains the CII badge https://github.com/osquery/osquery
sites_password_security_justification: Project site does not store credentials
maintenance_or_update_justification: Versions over the last several years are available https://osquery.io/downloads/
vulnerability_report_credit_justificatio: This is achieved via GitHub project Security Advisories https://github.com/osquery/osquery/security/advisories?state=published
vulnerability_response_process_justifica: This is documented in the Security Policy on GitHub https://github.com/osquery/osquery/security/policy
coding_standards_justification: The project uses a Clang Format configuration to communicate coding policy https://github.com/osquery/osquery/blob/master/.clang-format and enforces this via CI
coding_standards_enforced_justification: See above and the corresponding build requirement https://github.com/osquery/osquery/blob/master/.github/workflows/build.yml that enforces style checks.
build_standard_variables_justification: Met, with the use of CMake throughout the project.
build_preserve_debug_justification: There are several options to control the debug flags https://github.com/osquery/osquery/blob/master/cmake/options.cmake but the standard CMake options for building debug versions is the supported and recommended method.
build_non_recursive_justification: The inter-directory dependencies are explicitly stated for each build target within CMake.
build_repeatable_justification: Building the project on Linux, then removing all build configuration and artifacts and retrying the build produces the same bit-for-bit binary artifacts.
installation_standard_variables_justific: CMake allows a person building and installing the software to select the installation root.
external_dependencies_justification: All of the third-party libraries are defined in CMake https://github.com/osquery/osquery/tree/master/libraries
dependency_monitoring_justification: Updates to dependencies are updated in response to known vulnerabilities and new desired feature requests.
updateable_reused_components_justificati: Here is an example of the above https://github.com/osquery/osquery/commit/0e9efb1497037ded21e8679dda09547d5b0fecd0 demonstrating how one may update a third-party dependency.
interfaces_current_justification: This is done to the extent possible, however it is a product feature for osquery to be "widely deployable" meaning support on Linux for glibc 2.12 and greater.
automated_integration_testing_justificat: This is facilitated by CMake and CTest, instructions are found within the building documentation https://osquery.readthedocs.io/en/latest/development/building/
test_policy_mandated_justification: The Pull Request template asks contributors to check that their features include tests https://github.com/osquery/osquery/blob/master/.github/PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE.md
implement_secure_design_justification: The contributing guidelines and "first principles" implement a safe by default policy https://github.com/osquery/osquery/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#guidelines-for-contributing-features-to-osquery-core
input_validation_justification: There are various controls for restricting SQLite functionality, which tables are available at runtime, but the goal is to support any SQL input.
signed_releases_justification: The published packages are signed to the extent possible and documentation is on the website https://osquery.io/downloads/official/4.7.0
contributors_unassociated_justification:
osquery receives significant contributions from many people. Some top ones from 2020:
* @theopolis (Facebook)
* @smjert (Trail of Bits)
* @mike-myers-tob (Trail of Bits)
* @alessandrogario (Trail of Bits)
* @directionless (Kolide)

See https://github.com/osquery/osquery/graphs/contributors for contributors and https://github.com/orgs/osquery/teams/technical-steering-committee for the steering committee membership
copyright_per_file_justification: All source files include the osquery copyright header. This is checked by CI.
license_per_file_justification: All source files include the osquery header, which includes SPDX license tags
small_tasks_justification: Met, with the use of https://github.com/osquery/osquery/labels/easy and https://github.com/osquery/osquery/labels/good-first-issue
two_person_review_justification: All osquery contributions are required to go through GitHub's Pull Request review, and require signoff from at least one other core contributor.  (This is enforced by GitHub)
test_statement_coverage90_justification: Link to instructions on running the tests https://osquery.readthedocs.io/en/latest/development/building/#testing but statement coverage is not measured (?)
assurance_case_justification: We have a document in the root directory that explains all of these points. https://github.com/osquery/osquery/blob/master/ASSURANCE.md

repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: Our Git repository contains all versions, and we release Alpha, Beta, and RC as well as final releases.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification: We follow SemVer2 as our versioning scheme: https://github.com/helm/helm/releases
release_notes_justification: Our release notes are here: https://github.com/helm/helm/releases
report_process_justification:
We use GitHub Issues to track all bugs

https://github.com/helm/helm/issues
report_responses_justification:
We have weekly triage duty that rotates through the team of core maintainers. Our goal is to respond within 2 business days. https://github.com/helm/helm/issues

We have over 2700 issues closed, and 2700 PRs merged.
report_archive_justification:
The Helm issue queue is always available and is searchable
https://github.com/helm/helm/issues
vulnerability_report_process_justificati:
Top level contacts are in the root of the repo: https://github.com/helm/helm/blob/master/SECURITY_CONTACTS
Detailed instructions are here: https://github.com/helm/helm/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#reporting-a-security-issue
vulnerability_report_private_justificati:
Top level contacts are in the root of the repo: https://github.com/helm/helm/blob/master/SECURITY_CONTACTS
Embargo policy is here: https://github.com/kubernetes/sig-release/blob/master/security-release-process-documentation/security-release-process.md#embargo-policy
vulnerability_report_response_justificat:
Unfortunately, because all submissions are confidential, we have no public record of time, but we have kept response times to 12 days from first report to issued patch. In most cases, it's less.

Last example: https://github.com/helm/helm/releases/tag/v2.12.2
test_justification: CircleCI runs our automated tests: https://circleci.com/gh/helm/helm
test_invocation_justification: The `go test` command works, and we have a `make test` wrapper.
test_policy_justification: The developer's guide covers expectations. When a PR is submitted, the user must check a checkbox saying that they have included tests.
tests_are_added_justification: Git records this information, and we collect user verification in PRs. Example PR: https://github.com/helm/helm/pull/6243
tests_documented_added_justification: Detailed policy is here: https://github.com/helm/helm/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md (Esp. at the bottom)
warnings_justification:
The `make test` target, run by CI, runs comprehensive linting. We use a tool called Go Metalinter.

Script: https://github.com/helm/helm/blob/master/scripts/validate-go.sh
warnings_fixed_justification:
Certain warnings are blockers, and automated testing will fail until they are fixed. PRs are not merged until automated testing passes.

There are some warnings (usually aesthetic in nature) that the user is advised to fix, but which are not required.
warnings_strict_justification: Certain code aesthetic issues are not treated as PR blockers. Examples: Extra newlines at file's end. All functional checks, including dead code checks, will keep the PR from merging, though.
know_secure_design_justification: The following developers are designated for this role: https://github.com/helm/helm/blob/master/SECURITY_CONTACTS
know_common_errors_justification: The following developers are designated for this role: https://github.com/helm/helm/blob/master/SECURITY_CONTACTS
static_analysis_justification: Or linter runs static checks using the Go Staticcheck library.
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: Our code is run through GolangCI-Lint, which is a metalinter that includes the `staticcheck` static analyzer: https://github.com/golangci/golangci-lint. For details on staticcheck, see https://staticcheck.io/
crypto_weaknesses_justification: We sign with SHA256 and SHA512. We use GnuPG with large keys.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
hardening_justification: Where applicable, we use hardening mechanisms. Constant time compares for cryptographic significant comparisons, support for signing charts, etc. are used whenever fitting.
crypto_used_network_justification: We use TLS/SSL for communication with external APIs. Helm 2 provides mTLS support for client-server communication with Tiller. Helm 3 provides support for all of the built-in security mechanisms in the Kubernetes client.
crypto_tls12_justification: We support the latest version that core Go crypto libraries support, which at present is TLS 1.2 and 1.3
crypto_verification_private_justificatio: This is built into the Go TLS libraries
hardened_site_justification: // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
installation_common_justification: We support multiple installation and distribution channels, including building from source and systems like Homebrew. There is also an online installer: https://github.com/helm/helm/blob/master/scripts/get
governance_justification: Helm has a detailed governance document: https://github.com/helm/community/tree/master/governance
code_of_conduct_justification: Helm's Code of Conduct is inherited from the CNCF, and is linked from the main project README: https://github.com/helm/helm/blob/master/code-of-conduct.md
roles_responsibilities_justification: The project has detailed documentation about this, including onboarding guides and governance docs: https://github.com/helm/community
access_continuity_justification: The repo is jointly run by the Helm core maintainers and CNCF. Access to all supporting Helm services including websites, security settings, and keyrings are jointly editable by core maintainers. We use secure sharing via Keybase and LastPass to protect this information. The details are not shared, for security reasons, but the onboarding guide gives an overview: https://github.com/helm/community/blob/master/helm-maintainers-onboarding-guide.md
bus_factor_justification: The list of org maintainers includes all of those who have top-level permissions: https://github.com/helm/community/blob/master/MAINTAINERS.md
documentation_roadmap_justification: We use GitHub milestones to track short term releases, and a proposal/acceptance process for longer term planning: https://github.com/helm/community/tree/master/helm-v3 and https://github.com/helm/helm/milestones
documentation_architecture_justification: The architecture section of our documentation: https://helm.sh/docs/architecture/
documentation_security_justification: The "Securing Helm" guide covers security and best practices: https://helm.sh/docs/using_helm/#securing-your-helm-installation
documentation_current_justification:
The canonical documentation is tracked in a GitHub repository where designated documentation maintainers take care of it: https://github.com/helm/helm/tree/master/docs

We are in the process of further improving this process, creating a designated documentation project.
documentation_achievements_justification: This has been added to the main README for our next release branch and is staged for merge into master on release of Helm 3: https://github.com/helm/helm/tree/dev-v3
accessibility_best_practices_justificati: The main Helm.sh website follows, to the best of our knowledge, best practices for accessibility: https://helm.sh/
internationalization_justification: The Helm documentation site supports internationalized content, and current efforts are underway to produce complete English, Korean, and Chinese translations: https://github.com/helm/helm-www/tree/master/i18n
sites_password_security_justification: We do not offer website services that store passwords or tokens
maintenance_or_update_justification: We strictly adhere to SemVer, provide notices of any breaking changes, and provide upgrade paths when possible. With the transition from Helm 2 to Helm 3, we are preparing both documentation and software to assist in migrations.
vulnerability_report_credit_justificatio: We publish disclosures that give credit, and before giving credit we ask permission from the disclosing individual(s). https://helm.sh/blog/helm-security-notice-2019/index.html
vulnerability_response_process_justifica:
Information on filing security issues: https://github.com/helm/helm/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#reporting-a-security-issue
Information on how we handle vulnerabilities: https://github.com/helm/community/blob/master/SECURITY.md
coding_standards_justification: We follow the industry standard Go coding style, and provide details here: https://github.com/helm/helm/blob/master/docs/developers.md
coding_standards_enforced_justification: Our Makefile has a style checker, and this is run automatically by CI: https://github.com/helm/helm/blob/dev-v3/Makefile#L79-L82
build_standard_variables_justification: We use the standard Go toolchain, and provide hooks for overriding build configuration when necessary. The Makefile controls this.
build_preserve_debug_justification:
The Makefile does not suppress this information: https://github.com/helm/helm/blob/dev-v3/Makefile
The CI system captures information for latest builds so we can review issues on PRs
build_non_recursive_justification: The Go toolchain handles this automatically.
installation_development_quick_justifica: The Makefile has an optional `make bootstrap` target to do this: https://github.com/helm/helm/blob/dev-v3/Makefile
external_dependencies_justification: We have an exhaustive list that tracks dependencies down to the SHA: https://github.com/helm/helm/blob/dev-v3/Gopkg.lock
dependency_monitoring_justification: This is a responsibility of the core maintainers, but is assisted by GitHub Security Alerts.
updateable_reused_components_justificati: We use Go package management tools for this.
interfaces_current_justification: This is a part of our regular code maintenance.
automated_integration_testing_justificat: We use CircleCI, and it is run against every PR: https://circleci.com/gh/helm/helm
regression_tests_added50_justification: While we do not formally distinguish between regression tests and unit tests, Helm 3 requires contributors to provide test coverage for both features and bug fixes.
test_statement_coverage80_justification: We are currently at 70%+, but not yet at 80%
implement_secure_design_justification: This is part of core maintainers' reviews of PRs.
input_validation_justification: Helm does not ship with untrusted repositories. To add a repository, a user must explicitly run a command, upon which that repo is "whitelisted".
crypto_algorithm_agility_justification: This is provided via the OpenPGP specification and the TLS 1 specification. We use libraries compliant to these speifications.
crypto_credential_agility_justification: Credentials are loaded from external sources (files) and are never hardcoded or cached.
signed_releases_justification:
Our releases are signed, checksummed, and the public keys are published.
https://github.com/helm/helm/releases
https://github.com/helm/helm/blob/master/KEYS
version_tags_signed_justification: All recent releases are signed. We only add tags for releases. https://github.com/helm/helm/releases
assurance_case_justification: Our security assurance case is available here: https://github.com/helm/community/tree/master/security-assurance-case
